task_summary: Perceive the T-shaped block, align the circular tool, and push it leftwards toward the target outline, with periodic re-alignment. Control/observation at 10 Hz.

task_long_description.overview: A UR-style manipulator with a circular end-effector must push a T-shaped block across a white tabletop until it matches a target region. The contact sheet shows the red T initially to the right and a blue T-outline on the left, used as a proxy target. The robot approaches, aligns its yaw, performs a long push, briefly re-aligns, then executes a fine push. The sequence assumes 10 Hz sensing and control, favoring short timeouts and tight alignment to maintain stable contact during planar pushing.
preconditions: Workspace clear except for the T-block and target outline
Camera provides block pose at 10 Hz
No grasp is required; pure pushing
stepwise_plan: Perceive T-block; if not visible, scan raster.
Move above the block and descend to pre-push height.
Align tool to block edge and set yaw = 90°.
Execute a long push toward the target (≈0.2 m, 180°).
Re-align to correct drift and orientation.
success_criteria: T-block overlaps the target region outline
No loss of contact causing large orientation error
failure_and_recovery: Perception failure → raster scan and re-detect
Misalignment/slip → re-run ApproachAndAlign before another push
Timeout during push → retry with shorter segment
task_long_description.termination: Tree completes after retreat and wait once pushes finish, or any action returns failure beyond retries/timeouts.

frame_3.now_evidence: first stable contact and alignment cue visible
frame_3.predicts_next: push actuation expected; confirms goal direction

task_instruction: The task requires pushing a T-shaped block (gray) to a fixed target (green) with a circular end-effector (blue). Both observation and control frequencies are 10Hz.

node_specs.description: Checks if the T-block is currently visible.
Raster scan to locate the T-block if not immediately visible.
Perception call to estimate block pose.
Move above the block at a safe pre-push height.
Refine lateral pose to make a straight pushing contact.
Rotate tool to align with pushing edge.
Primary long push toward the target region.
Re-align after drift before fine push.
Fine push to settle into the target.
Back away to avoid disturbing final pose.

assumptions: Frames show a red T and a blue outline, whereas instruction mentions gray block and green target; we use the blue outline as the effective target.
Push direction assumed leftward (180°) based on frame 4–7 motion.
Circular tool appears black with blue housing; treated as ‘circular end-effector (blue)’ per instruction.

expected_success_criteria: T-block’s centroid lies inside/overlaps the outline region
Yaw error small after final push
